title: Secondary – Cycle 1– Progression of Learning - English as a Second Language (2010)
subject: Languages

A6B631EE66344438ACB3129BB60E7341.description: Shares draft with others for feedback

EE58F56AFBCB41EEB4BFD3076DBB50AA.description: Selects appropriate language (e.g. vocabulary, level of formality)

D6DE2762547445258ADAC72C45BDCC0A.description: Answers guiding questions individually and expands on prompts that deal with issues from texts at a broader level

D18E42639E9946C8BBE37407C6B25A47.description: Shares personal connections to texts with others to deepen understanding

8057049F5BDD420D9AAC4FD134414446.description: Answers guiding questions individually and expands on prompts to make personal connections with texts

86960D1CE31547439E198E6B01200601.description: Answers guiding questions individually and expands on prompts that deal with the underlying meaning of texts

82C46DCCE8734EC99E78DDB3CF568A5F.description: Answers guiding questions individually and expands on prompts that deal with the literal meaning of texts

0C0E75A96F8E4BD69BECF834954D1893.description: Uses self-evaluation means to reflect on the effectiveness of a specific social/affective strategy (e.g. self-evaluation grid, class discussion)

FB6F4249118D43578F7B1754AE5581DF.description: Pushes oneself to experiment with language and ideas without fear of making errors

D7D958BA8064469ABB52781543C4459E.description: Reduces stress by reminding self of goals, progress made and resources available

89FAEC9B85F84CEEAE9CBCE1BCD90421.description: Makes positive statements during a task and congratulates self and others upon completion

A540A0A85FA44009BBBF7810C59A4B30.description: Encourage and reward self and others

FEC969766CDC49F6A614AE11EB21132A.description: Works with others to achieve a common goal

D595856DBAC64443BD181BF4776B7F0C.description: Requests assistance, reiteration, precision and reinforcement

5B54A478FE054BE880667ADE184EDDD5.description: Ask for help, repetition, clarification, confirmation

06EAFC5D9000488CB4D10140B29E8495.description: Uses self-evaluation means to reflect on the effectiveness of a specific cognitive strategy (e.g. self-evaluation grid, class discussion

95697ADAFC9343DD98679E17BF635EBD.description: Groups ideas in meaningful clusters to visually represent relationships between concepts.

361D473636CA467BA97E6C7A506EA293.description: Writes down relevant information in an organized way (e.g. graphic organizers, guiding questions, prompts)

A69E61DEDDA847BCBC139A390FFE964F.description: Reads through a text quickly to get a general overview

F00AB36C7A8A4837B6E99BA9E277BC1C.description: Looks for specific information in a text

D0B2239094A8429EA9F1828C4A6E74A4.description: Constructs a meaningful sentence by putting together known words and expressions in a new way

83BFB9C2E5CA472B921F6C2EDE753CB0.description: Makes hypotheses based on prior knowledge, topic, task at hand, text components or glancing through a text

5A887B7F0EBF43A7A1676545F1F47FED.description: Reuses language learned in the ESL class

2347D6D6C0EE4A7BAF605742CC8F3332.description: Makes intelligent guesses based on prior knowledge of cues such as context, cognates, expressions, visual clues, intonation

64897618DF5C4FB683EC1B58EEC92C6B.description: Takes time to listen and speak when ready

F04A4DA26E1A4D84A44EB62EFB7E4B3C.description: Links new information to what is already known

913CA316543042A09C5EA355718ED3F6.description: Cognitive Strategies, Strategies used to manipulate and interact with the material to be learned.

79F16BF2E8DB46C0AFE87CC0150579B8.description: Uses self-evaluation means to reflect on the effectiveness of a specific metacognitive strategy (e.g. self-evaluation grid, class discussion)

4FFA8C6DCD9F43538551FF2CB34EBE5B.description: Assesses own progress by reflecting on what has been learned and how

E87D652932264CE689D7670B6CA0C03A.description: Identifies the necessary elements to carry out a task

427DC200CB1747A79EE108CC15615389.description: Decides in advance to concentrate on particular details

DFB1E1A8AAAE4FC7B8031C0C6798ADE9.description: Maintains attention during task by purposely avoiding distracters

28778C1DB8C64867B9A45CC6AA087CF0.description: Metacognitive Strategies Strategies used to regulate learning

F06DDD7305E24C5EB3938FA070E0E761.description: Uses self-evaluation means to reflect on the effectiveness of a specific communication strategy (e.g. self-evaluation grid, class discussion)

1D68A6490C274992B2316C259C51F284.description: Uses less precise words or expressions to replace unknown ones

45023889E41F4ECB820B55AE6690FC07.description: Buys time to think out a response

DDC38623569F43B08EAA0E4228EC04AA.description: Restates what someone else has just said to verify comprehension

598C418BBD2449FA8B09876FD670D1EE.description: Uses physical actions to convey or support messages

49E25985627141418BAA267DC63800F2.description: Communication Strategies,Strategies used to solve problems related to participating in and maintaining interaction

A75959864313471191463F19618F4B09.description: Uses targeted grammatical structures to express oral and written messages

A9EF3C715AA64F47BEBE954198F64D94.description: Uses knowledge of targeted grammatical structures to construct meaning of oral and written messages

70547231CA024643B3EFDFEBBF1FFF23.description: Uses targeted mechanics to write and produce texts

1860FF7EE88A4F3BB5B3EECCA3CBA681.description: Uses knowledge of targeted mechanics to construct meaning of texts

6E33AB36F1844E46AAE7A86F5B386644.description: Uses appropriate stress and pronunciation for targeted words to carry out tasks (e.g. Chocolate: \' chä-clate\)

A2D554E724F644C1A24FD661F7CD0F1E.description: Uses appropriate stress and pronunciation for words frequently used to participate in classroom life (e.g. Wednesday: \' wenz-day\)

6DB748AAB2F74AE99640330054FB53AC.description: Uses rising and falling voice pitch to convey meaning (e.g. rising voice pitch to express surprise: It’s snowing?_?)

CB38B2CDFA104B41850464B9EBC259F2.description: Uses targeted vocabulary related to texts (e.g. text components: subtitles)

B747F5C4714F4660ABE7D7DE507CE888.description: Uses targeted vocabulary related to language conventions (i.e. intonation, pronunciation and grammar) (e.g. talk: silent letter 'l')

F5E973634D634A4DBBE84333173D7DDD.description: Uses targeted vocabulary related to the response, writing and production processes (e.g. response process: exploring, connecting, generalizing)

3D3C702BE8B2438F9BD844A8C84037AE.description: Uses targeted vocabulary related to communication and learning strategies (e.g. skim: quick read)

A943183C4B5A451587D2F4A01EE74A01.description: Uses targeted vocabulary related to the development of the cross-curricular competencies: Uses information (e.g. source), Solves problems (e.g. solution), Exercises critical judgment (e.g. viewpoints) Uses creativity (e.g. trial and error) Adopts effective work methods (e.g. process), Uses information and communications technologies (e.g. networks),Achieves his/her potential (e.g. autonomy), Cooperates with others (e.g. teammates) Communicates appropriately (e.g. audience)

F20878F37E714934BF09091F3381C9FD.description: Uses targeted vocabulary related to issues inspired by the broad areas of learning: Health and Well-Being (e.g. hygiene), Personal and Career Planning (Cycle 1) / Career Planning and Entrepreneurship (Cycle 2) (e.g. occupations), Environmental Awareness and Consumer Rights and Responsibilities (e.g. pollution) Media Literacy (e.g. copyrights), Citizenship and Community Life (e.g. democracy)

7C509956AAA1494CB44E232601CBF85E.description: Uses targeted vocabulary related to students’ interests and needs such as leisure activities, relationships, jobs (e.g. sports equipment

B16CD450A9E1425C810F6BB5F95DD608.description: Uses targeted vocabulary related to the immediate environment such as classroom, home, community (e.g. stapler

A5957D62426F463AA2AEE5E90A61610C.description: Uses discourse markers to link ideas (e.g. Then…, Next…, On the other hand…)

65CB35F03B8144E19E0AC23C7880A5B4.description: Contributes to teamwork and harmonious exchanges (e.g. Do you want to be on our team? Interesting idea! Good work!)

AA6B3BFB537A477585EB7CC9360C3304.description: Accepts or refuses invitations (e.g. Yes, I’d love to! I can’t make it. Sounds good to me.)

72D7B0F09EA94C85B8C33FC4A3CECEF8.description: Invites others (e.g. Let’s go to…, Would you like to…? Do you want to join us?)

937FBD96444E4F95A4A158533B04A823.description: Asks for suggestions (e.g. Should I…? What do you suggest? Do you have a suggestion?)

CE13CB1DEFBA4CA0A34F5E321CB8CCBF.description: Makes suggestions (e.g. Let’s…, Maybe you should…, Why don’t we…?)

08668E737D464F78B1EDD8DC388AB1C8.description: Offers clarification (e.g. What I said was…, Let me explain..., I mean…)

AEBE561A14CF4A07B8F541401113CDC3.description: Asks for clarification (e.g. Could you repeat, please? Can you say that another way? What does… mean?)

7E6C5F44D5A748E5B8ED8EB50EE316C3.description: Asks information questions (e.g. Who/What/Where/When/Why/How...? Does he…? Can they…? Are you...?)

0658D314E1DE43ECBBB8D5591F2F0D50.description: Asks about needs, wants and obligations (e.g. What do they need? What does she want? What do we have to do?)

73C82DE3E11346399A11DBDB658967DE.description: Expresses needs, wants and obligations (e.g. They need…, I really want…, We must…) a.

1B468A79CCAE4A17BE130ED226395B2F.description: Offers help/assistance (e.g. Do you want me to help you? I can help you with…, Let me give you a hand.)

14D3370C8BAD4CE08BC5AF9A4D4E1D88.description: Accepts or declines offers of help/assistance (e.g. No thanks. Sure, that’s fine. Yes, I’ll help you.)

B4A5CAA9720A4995BC2A2B390C0BBC99.description: Asks for help/assistance (e.g. How do you write…? How would you do this? Can you help me with…?)

AB502FCF444B408EB11D4ED49EF41332.description: Participates in classroom life (e.g. Write this down. I would like to work with…, How was your weekend?)

1692632703664992899176CE5F4CF7D9.description: Asks for advice and feedback (e.g. What would you do? Could you give me your feedback on this? Would you have a look at …?)

F6E324E0CD9B464C820FDBF922B3AAA3.description: Gives advice and feedback (e.g. Why don’t you try…, If I were you, I would…, You could…)

9AF6E04D117E40189240503FD380414E.description: Gives/refuses permission (e.g. Yes, go ahead. No you can’t. Sure, no problem.)

167919F4785B4CDDA45CEFACE2EB47A7.description: Asks for permission (e.g. May/Can I…? Do you mind if…? Is it all right if…?)

0583B320998D4C22806AB2D230DF0954.description: Asks about others’ decision/indecision (e.g. What have you decided? Have you made up your mind? What’s your decision?)

3255C5EB3DA74BF4B453EB8FA9B8B374.description: Expresses decision/indecision (e.g. I decided that…, We choose this one. I’m not sure about this.)

61159DF2F8B84FB2BC34778B03D20579.description: Asks about others’ interests, tastes and preferences (e.g. Which would you prefer? What’s your favourite…? Why do you like. . .?)

9BD7A3633C2D418F854136DE85C1A162.description: Expresses interests, tastes and preferences (e.g. They like…, I can’t stand…, She prefers…)

235B80BDA7D346299C9B11610E75BA26.description: Asks about others’ feelings (e.g. How do you feel about…? Are you okay? Why is she sad?)

9B7E1AD3718845D8882DBEEB6F4C69B3.description: Expresses feelings (e.g. I’m thrilled. She feels…, They're happy.)

C60DF6B49A1045F1B2210EEAB8A54A39.description: Asks about capabilities (e.g. Do they know how to…? Can it…? Are you good at…?)

31929A58A31C46C1A7091BB688082BA7.description: Expresses capabilities (e.g. He’s good at…, They are unable to…, I can/can’t…)

B94BBE5E02F64CB88D735FA038E0C92D.description: Asks others to support their opinions (e.g. Why do you say that? Why are you against…? What are your arguments?)

7F8919600B6D4ECAB10BB5DE90B60C21.description: Supports opinions (e.g. I believe this because..., For example…, Based on the text…)

53DA6E494EA544E6AA6010682474E308.description: Asks for others’ opinions (e.g. What do you think? What’s your opinion? Is he for or against…?)

2C78C03C400F431E983A19E329322AFB.description: States opinions (e.g. In my opinion…, I think that…, I’m for/against…)

1B9865A84A8942AAA3F627D4CAEADED3.description: Asks if others are in agreement/disagreement (e.g. Do you agree? Who disagrees? Are you okay with…?)

5335FFF270854FC1B83AE3F2C68D8E06.description: Expresses agreement/disagreement (e.g. Me too. I don’t think so. We don’t agree with...)

A35F1C43D7AD4B0EA13619FB0C9CA834.description: Gives warnings (e.g. Watch out! Be careful! You’d better not…)

8E876E17F9AD46C2A7D09420A69E3514.description: Invites other speakers to contribute to exchanges and to maintain interaction (e.g. What about you? Are you sure? What’s your point of view?)

CB52A81023E54D68B61DF65ECDEEC362.description: Fills in pauses to maintain exchanges (e.g. I mean…, You know…, Well…)

5A9E51BCB01A483895710D7538B272A8.description: Indicates that more time is needed to figure out what to say and how to say it (e.g. Just a minute. Wait a second. Let me think.)

3B4A5015EDCC44E1BD899E2F879267D5.description: Asks about events, experiences, ideas and issues (e.g. What does it look like? Can you tell me more about...)

380A7798D5374D579C56CFDFCF066037.description: Describes events, experiences, ideas and issues (e.g. This is about…, It was the best day of my life because...)

11C64E892B1F41AF98027D920FB583F5.description: Asks about people, animals, objects, places (e.g. Who are they? Where is it? What’s your…?)

52D0DAA9F06642168E605E98A23EC61F.description: Describes basic characteristics of people, animals, objects, places (e.g. He looks..., This is a..., She is very intelligent.)

33DC6F9BD48E4CD382F3168F206E1060.description: nterrupts a conversation politely (e.g. Excuse me. Sorry to interrupt, but…, Before you continue…)

956C0EAE577F481FBF3296BF32BC1819.description: Apologizes and responds to apologies (e.g. I apologize. Sorry, I didn’t mean to…, Don’t worry about it.)

484AF0D93DC84761B891BEFB78922BF4.description: Begins/ends telephone exchanges and uses voice mail (e.g. Hello, I’m calling about…,Thank you for calling. Please leave a message after the beep.)

BF7EB568B6304670A8806B6EFC6E5CE6.description: Uses expressions of courtesy (e.g. Please. Thank you very much! You’re more than welcome.)

0A401172D751417E8BE9FD689253B6E0.description: Takes leave (e.g. Take care! See you later! I have to go.)

258671C4910A4010A31BA32B790682F6.description: Greets and responds to greetings (e.g. How are you? Not so bad, and you? What’s new?)

B2A20EF73358446C8F8C0C54F8D03B82.description: Compares communication conventions from English-language cultures with own culture

B951A88A29A947F2AD460A590DD8C046.description: Explores communication conventions from English-language cultures

F619A49FBBB1466CB2280273D253B5F4.description: Sociolinguistic Aspect (i.e. communication conventions such as social conventions, paralinguistic skills, language code, humour)

1DC259B6A8F347C5A41353D9D803FD3C.description: Compares daily life practices from English-language cultures with own culture

8A56AB4D61AB498581E9B99EDEDF5183.description: Explores daily life practices from English-language cultures

1028C58F16034F39B85F5A488A88FBE2.description: Sociological Aspect (i.e. daily life practices related to areas such as family, relationships, pastimes, customs, heroes, history)

75B021F15A134A4BB8EE14EA7D7E6798.description: Compares cultural products from English-language cultures with own culture

AC7AEF3F0E6F49DEB9771F41AC863181.description: Explores cultural products from English-language cultures

25085FBD43CA4358942EB24286A1C966.description: Aesthetic Aspect( i.e. cultural products such as cinema, literature, music, media that represent Englishlanguage cultures)
